Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Development of a Safety System for Individuals with Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is a safety system for improving the quality and reducing the cost of dementia care. Alzheimer's disease affects 5.4M in the US, including 1 in 9 over 65 and 1 in 3 over 85, and represents two thirds of all those affected by dementia. Despite that Alzheimer's disease is the single most expensive disease in the US and falls are the leading cause of hospitalization in Alzheimer's care, current tools offer little support. Although 3/4 of elderly fallers will experience a repeat fall, solutions like bed alarms and wearable fall detection systems offer no way to see how falls occur. Care staff have no way of learning from the first fall to reduce the likelihood of the second and must implement painful and expensive policies such as sending every unwitnessed fall to the emergency room in case a hit to the head occurred.

The proposed project addresses this critical gap in Alzheimer's care by detecting falls based on camera video where falls can be reviewed by a human assistant in real-time and after the fact. Real-time review allows for instant notification if a hit to the head occurred, and review after the fact allows for determining the cause of the fall to see if changes in room layout and/or policy could be made. The primary aim of this project is to collect video data of real falls 1) to apply and extend state-of-the-art deep learning methods to perform high accuracy detection and 2) to validate that affected individuals, family, and care staff are accepting of a camera-based solution. Fall detection will be performed by extending the Region-Based Convolutional Neural Network (RCNN) algorithm using domain adaptation techniques developed to robustly handle night-vision camera operation, occlusion, and non-standard human pose. Technical success will be measured by <1% missed detection and <50% false positive rate from this feasibility study. This first accuracy threshold will define a lower bound where, as has been demonstrated repeatedly in the deep-learning paradigm, accuracy will continue to improve as more data is collected.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most expensive disease in the US ($236B yearly direct costs; $221B yearly indirect). New approaches for resolving key contributors to the cost of care are critically needed. Fall injury is the leading contributor of AD-related hospitalizations with estimated annual Medicare cost of $5.3B). In memory care facilities where the majority of fall events occur, individuals with dementia (patients) fall 4.05 times/year on average versus 2.33 times/year for other residents. There is at the present time no complete, extensive, and scalable solution that enables memory care facilities in the US and around the world to address the problem of falls and fall history. This is precisely the objective of SafelyYou, (formerly NestSense for Phase I submission).  As fall etiology is multifactorial, detecting the first fall and taking preventative action provides significant potential for understanding the often-unwitnessed circumstances of the fall and for reducing fall risk through secondary prevention. Enabling rapid fall detection from video limits the amount of time fallers spend on the ground and the need for unnecessary emergency room visits in the case of unwitnessed falls. Mary Tinetti, developer of the well-known Tinetti score for fall risk assessment, noted that the risks of time spent on the ground (due to a variety of reasons, i.e. inability to get up, duration before being helped, etc.) following a fall is associated with increased need for hospitalizations and mortality. Moreover, in these memory care facilities, if a patient is found on the ground (referred to as an unwitnessed fall), protocol requires the patient to be sent to the emergency room (ER) to see if a head injury occurred at a cost of roughly $4500 of which 80% is covered by Medicare. If a fall is witnessed, the existing protocol requires care staff to report a possible head injury and perform an assessment for a fracture in the memory care facility preventing the ER visit. 

During this award period, we recruited 11 facilities to take part in initial data collection, built a prototype system for collecting video data and delivering reviews from our occupational therapist on how falls could be prevented by on post-fall review, recruited approximately 100 patients to participate from these facilities, deployed the system in these 11 memory care facilities, and demonstrated the ability to detect falls using algorithms applied to video alone after the fact. Specifically, we showed 3 key outcomes:

  1. Operations: deployment of our system, testing of the technology, recruitment of the patients. The key outcome here is an overall acceptance of video monitoring technology in the private rooms within memory care where the privacy-security tradeoff is greatly shifted.
  2. Systems work: building our software and hardware platform for our research study. The key outcome here was a system composed of off-the-shelf hardware and custom software which allowed for collecting video, performing OT reviews, and sharing video when appropriate.
  3. Algorithms: development of machine learning algorithms to achieve the real-time detection. The key outcome here was success in developing and applying fall detection algorithms used after-the-fact. That is, we showed algorithms that would detect all fall events we recorded and generate one false alarm per patient per month if applied in real time.

As we move forward, we hope to apply a system for detecting fall-events in real-time to study the extent to which emergency help can be received faster when needed and can be avoided when unneeded. To what extent the algorithms here generalize to an arbitrary fall event has yet to be seen.
